chunks.title: co

chunks.text: After we resolve this function, a value is returned.

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: 3. This function becomes negative 1.

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's write something a little more complex.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will create a function to create a full name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Create name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll need two parameters for a first name and a last name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll name these first and last.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: What do we want to do within this function?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's capitalize the user's first name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: First, equals first.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Capitalize method.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then do the same thing with the last name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Last equals last. Capitalize.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then I'm going to return the user's first name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Plus their last name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then I'll add a space in between their first and last name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This is also valid.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Outside of the function, let's create a full name variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then invoke the create name function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This function is going to capitalize the first last name for us.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll type in my first name, all lowercase, same thing with my last name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then let's print our full name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Here's my full name variable.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We sent our function some arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have some parameters set up.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We took those values, made them uppercase, then concatenated these strings together.

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: SpongeBob.

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Using the return statement, you can return some data back to the place in which you call a function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Well, everybody, that's a function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It's a section of reusable code.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: To call a function, you type the functions name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Add a set of parentheses.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You can send a function some data, which are known as arguments, but you'll need a matching set of parameters.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You also do have the option of returning some data back to the place in which you invoke a function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll be using functions along the future, but we will get more practice with them.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And those are functions in Python.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Hey, everybody. Today I'm going to explain default arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Default arguments are a default value for certain parameters.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The default is used when that argument is omitted when you invoke a function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: In the last topic, we discussed positional arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Today, we will be examining default arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then in future topics, we'll examine keyword and arbitrary arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's begin. Let's define a function to calculate net price.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There will be three parameters.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: An original list price.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A discount if there is one.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And sales tax.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will return a net price.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And here's the formula.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: List price times one minus our discount percentage times one plus our sales tax.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Maybe I'm buying a PlayStation 5 for $500.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will pass in $500 for the list price.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Well, I can't actually execute this function without also passing in an argument for discount and tax.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Perhaps the discount is zero.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And the sales tax is 5%.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Well, this would work.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And I should probably put this within a print statement so you can see it.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And there we are.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: My total is $525.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The list price of $500.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: No discount.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And 5% sales tax.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now suppose that maybe 90% of the time when we're executing this function, most of the time discount is zero.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And our sales tax is almost always the same.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: What we could do to make this function a little more flexible is to set these two parameters to have a default value.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: In place of sending in three arguments, we can pass in one, then set our discount and our tax to have a default value.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So I will set discount to be zero and tax to be 0.05 meaning 5%.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So this function would work.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Our total is $525.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And that's assuming that our discount is zero and our tax is 5%.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The nice thing about using default arguments is that let's say that somebody has a discount.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And this function would also accept up to two additional arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So let's print our net price, 500, and our customer has a coupon for 10% off.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll add a second argument of 0.1.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If we're passing in an argument for our discount, we'll use whatever is passed in rather than the default.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The total now is $472.50 or maybe this time they are not paying sales tax.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will set the sales tax to be 0.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Now the customer's total is $450.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So that's kind of the nice thing about default arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It makes your functions more flexible and it can reduce the number of arguments, especially if the arguments that you're passing in tend to be consistent.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Most of the time people don't have a discount and almost everybody is paying 5% sales tax.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Why pass an argument if we don't have to?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's cover an exercise.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll create a count up timer.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will import the time module.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will define this function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Define count.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There will be two arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Start and end.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For x and range start comma and within the range function the second argument is exclusive.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So I'm going to add 1 to the end of our time.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then I will print x.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: To make this thread that's running the program sleep you can access the time modules sleep method pass in 1 for 1 second.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then outside of the for loop let's print the word done.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: To invoke this function I need to pass in two arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A start time and an end time.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll set the start time to be 0.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The end time to be 10.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: 10 seconds.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So we start at 0 then we will increment by 1 every second.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll speed up the video I think you get the idea but we'll stop at 10.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's assume that most of the time a user would like to begin at 0.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Well we don't necessarily need to pass that in as an argument.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's set our start parameter to have a default value of 0.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We only need to pass in one argument but we do have a problem.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Non default arguments should follow default arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So if you use any default arguments you'll want to be sure that they're after any positional arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So let's reverse these.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And that should work.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So now when I run this program it's assuming we'd like to start at 0.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But we'll need to pass in an ending amount of seconds when do we want to stop.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That works the same.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But now we do have the option of starting at a different number.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This time let's end at 30 but we will begin at 15.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We're beginning at 15 then we will count to 30.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll speed up the video.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There we are.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: All right everybody so in conclusion default arguments they are default values for certain parameters.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The default value is used when an argument is omitted.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: They can make your functions more flexible and reduce the number of arguments you have to pass in.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Especially if those arguments are consistent most of the time.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So those are default arguments and in the next topic we will discuss keyword arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And well yeah those are default arguments in Python.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Hey friends it's me again. Today I'm going to explain keyword arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A keyword argument is an argument preceded by an identifier.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It has a few benefits. It helps with readability and the order of the arguments doesn't matter if they're keywords.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Keyword arguments are one of four basic styles of arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We discussed positional default. Then next we'll discuss arbitrary.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But today we'll be focusing on keyword.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Suppose I have a function to display a message like a greeting.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will name this function the hello function.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will need a greeting, a title, Mr. Mrs. Doctor.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A first name, then a last name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: All I'm going to do within this function is print an upstring.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will print my greeting, the user's title, first name, last name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then to invoke the hello function, I will need to pass in four arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A greeting, a title, a first name, and a last name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So from my greeting let's say hello.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The title will be Mr. The first name will be SpongeBob, last name, squarepants.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So you know this does work. We're currently using positional arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The position of these arguments does matter. So what if I were to switch these around?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have hello SpongeBob, squarepants, followed by Mr.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Hello SpongeBob, squarepants, Mr.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: An optional feature when sending arguments to a function is that we could turn these into keyword arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Prefix any arguments with the name of the parameter followed by equals.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Title equals Mr.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: First equals SpongeBob, last equals squarepants.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then with these keyword arguments the order really doesn't matter.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Maybe we move the first name to the end.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And this still would print out as the same thing.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have title, first name, last name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If you're mixing and matching positional arguments and keyword arguments,

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: you want to be sure that the positional arguments are first.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So if I was to move the string, our greeting to the end.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Well, this technically wouldn't work.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have a syntax error.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Positional arguments follow keyword arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So make sure any positional arguments are first before using any keyword arguments.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Two helpful benefits of using keyword arguments is that it helps with readability

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: and the order of the arguments doesn't matter.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We know what this argument is as well as these two.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Title, last name, first name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's say we have a first name and a last name, John James.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: These two names kind of sound like first names.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Is our first name John or is it James?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We could use keyword arguments to clarify which is which.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You thought John was the first name, but it's actually the last name.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And the first name is James.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then our title is still the same.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Hello, Mr. James, John.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's cover another example.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'm going to print the numbers one through ten using a for loop.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For x and range, 1,11 because the second argument is exclusive.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then I will print x.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: After each print statement, we print a new line.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Do you remember in previous topics how we would follow our print statement with comma and then a new character such as a space?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Well, end is a keyword argument found within the built in print statement.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: In place of ending each print statement with a new line, we are using this keyword argument of end and sending it to be a space.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Another one is separate that's found within the print statement.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Maybe we have some numbers.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: They're all separate strings.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The numbers one through five.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I can use the separate keyword argument, then separate each of these strings with a given character or characters.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I will separate each of these strings with a dash.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A lot of built in functions such as the print function, they have some keyword arguments you can use.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's go over an exercise now.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We are going to create a function to generate a phone number.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But we'll need to pass in a country code, area code, the first three digits and the last four digits.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's define this function as define get phone to get a phone number.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have a country code, area code, first meaning first few digits, then last meaning last few digits.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will return an F string.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will place our country code first dash, then our area code, dash, the first few digits, dash, the last few digits.

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: My phone number, phone number equals, I will invoke the get phone number function we just created.

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
